subject: Re: [junit] JUnit not matching to my needs - execute order shows design flaw ?
msgSnippet: ... Ouch!  That s true. -- Jason Rogers 117 N. First Street Suite 90 Ann Arbor, MI 48104 Tel 734.302.7694 Fax 734.302.7694 Cel 734.846.5089
messageBody:
On Saturday 10 July 2004 03:35 pm, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Jason Rogers wrote:
> > On Wednesday 07 July 2004 10:49 pm, Curt Sampson wrote:
> >  >  On Tue, 6 Jul 2004, hedgi wrote:
> >  >  >   Now I there is the problem. I want to run "testCommon" first
> >  >  >   which is in the "BasicGetListTest" but when I subclass it with
> >  >  >   "GlucoseGetListTest" it is always executed last. I read some of
> >  >  >   the postings in this newsgroup, but it seems that such kind of
> >  >  >   requirement point a desing flaw and I should somehow rearrange
> > my >  >   Unit Test Structure to made the tests indepentdant. I'm stuck
> > with >  >   it.
> >  >
> >  >  I've been thinking for a while that this is a serious problem in
> > JUnit >  (and most unit testing frameworks), because it's been such an
> > annoyance >  for so many people. Let's face it; a lot of groups of tests
> > do have >  known dependencies between tests such that if test A fails,
> > we know that >  the output of tests B, C and D are uninteresting. Yet we
> > end up running >  B, C and D anyway, and then searching through all the
> > error output for >  the failure that we know is the "real" one, ignoring
> > all the others as >  spurious.
> >
> > With all due respect, I believe that is a code smell. 
>
> With equally great respect, even though the code smell, Curt must test it.

Ouch! That's true.

--
